Info
Signs And Symptopms
First Aid
Hypothermia
A condition when the entire body temperature falls.

Cold skin apathy, drowsiness, incoherence
Breathing rate sluggish pupilsïƒ“
Pulse rate uncontrollable shiveringïƒ“
Slow, thick speech apathy, drowsiness, incoherence
Staggering walk.

Check responsiveness
Cover with blanket
Apply hot compress
Check vital signs
Heat stroke or sunstroke
A response to heat characterized by extremely high body temperature and disturbance of sweating mechanism.

Raised body temperature
Dry hot red skin, dark urine.
Small pupils, rapid or shallow breathing,
Extreme confusion, Weakness
Seizures, Unconsciousness.

Cool the victim. (no alcohol rub)
Give First Aid for shock. Lay the victim flat
If the victim starts having seizures, give first aid for seizures.
Keep the victim cool as you await medical help.
Heart Attack
Impairment of heart function d/t inadequate blood flow to the heart compared to its needs, caused by obstructive changes in the coronary circulation.

Acute central chest pain not responding to nitrates
Pain radiating to neck/left arm
Associated with nausea 
 silent MI.

Give semi-sitting position
Reassure, immobilize
Call Ambulance
Angina medications 
Aspirin chewable
Monitor pulse breathing.
Diabetes
Low blood sugar level causes diabetics on insulin starvation.

History of diabetes
Excess hunger
Feeling faint or dizzy
Strange behavior â€“ Confusion, aggression
Palpitations, tremors
Pale, cold, sweaty skin
Loss of consciousness.

If conscious, give GLUCOSE orally till person feels better
If unconscious, monitor airway and breathing and seek medic help
Give glucagon injection (keep prefilled syringe in c/o diabetes)
If possible, give glucose.
Seizures or Fits
paroxysmal event due to abnormal, excessive, hyper synchronous discharges from an aggregate of CNS neurons.

Aura
Sudden rigidity of body â€“ tonic phase
Collapse d/t which injuries may be sustained
F/b periodic relaxation of muscles â€“ chronic phase.

Move person away from danger e.g. fire, water, furniture
Donâ€™t try to restrain
Donâ€™t insert anything in mouth
After convulsion ceases, give recovery position
Ensure airway is clear
Donâ€™t leave person alone even after seizure
Reassure, support
Call ambulance.
Asthma
Disease of airways choric. By increased responsiveness of the tracheobronchial tree to a variety of stimuli.

Shortness of breath\nChest tightness or pain\nTrouble sleeping caused by shortness of breath, coughing or wheezingn ï‚§ A whistling or wheezing sound when exhaling (wheezing is a common sign of asthma in children).

Help the Patient to Rest
Assist with medication
Help the patient take any â€˜relieverâ€™ medication they have
Call an ambulance immediately.
Triggers
Allergens during weather and season change, animal fur and dander, smoke, dust, aspirin, coloring agents, Air pollutants,Infections.

Shortness of breath
Cough
Chest tightness
Wheezing
Associated symptoms â€“ inability to speak, pale skin, blueness, distress, confusion
Ultimately â€“ unconscious and ceases to breathe.

Move away from the thing that triggered the episode
Take a quick relief asthma medication
Stay calm so that breathing gets better
Call Ambulance if:
No response to medication
Lips/fingernails turn blue or grey
Nasal flare
Skin is pulled around the neck and ribs when person breathes
Heartbeat/pulse is too fast.
Road Accident
Critical four minutes: One of the most common causes of a road accident death is due to loss of oxygen supply. Normally it takes less than four minutes for a blocked airway to cause death.

Beware of further collisions and fire
Alert oncoming traffic to the danger ahead
Donâ€™t allow anyone to smoke
Get assistance from bystanders
Call Ambulance
Donâ€™t move casualties who remain in their vehicles, unless they are in danger by doing so.
Never remove a motorcyclistâ€™s helmet unless deemed necessary.
Avoid unnecessary movements
Reassurance.
